At the time of this review, I own 316 steam games. This is not including games I own from other services, console games I currently own, and games owned in the past that are no longer in my posession. I have played thousands of games over the years, and let me tell you something.  Bad Rats is, without a doubt, the single greatest video game I have ever played. Now, I was only able to play for a total of 32 minutes, but those were the best 32 minutes of my entire life. Better than losing my virginity. Better than the first time I ever got intoxicated. Better than the first time I ever fell in love. Better than that time I found Jesus. No sir. In fact, if you took every achievement in human history and combined them together, they would still only measure up to a small fraction of the excellence that is Bad Rats.  It is with great sorrow that I can never play Bad Rats again, for it is so amazing in it's execution that mortal eyes can only behold it's magnificence for so long. It's much like an Elder Scroll, or the Ark of the Covenant. To stare directly at it for too long can only be met with death. This game was touched by God himself, and it shows in the expertly crafted gameplay and amazing audio that only the divine could hope to achieve.  If you do not have Bad Rats forever linked to your Steam account then I am sorry . . .But you are not a real gamer. Nay, I say, you are not even a real human. You have not fully lived until you direct your army of brave mouse warriors to slay the evil cat plague through a series of convoluted death traps. In fact, you should be sacrificing your own children to the Elder God's RIGHT NOW as thanks for this monumental game.  I give this game my full endorsement, now and always. 11/10. Monumental game. This game really shows the good side of indie devs.  I recently started a game in GameMaker thanks to this, it inspired me to make a whole new world of greatness. Bad rats has a amazing range of characters.  Like Rat, and the very malicious. Cat, with these dynamic characters, you've got yourself a fantastic story with endless possiblities.   Bad Rats has a unique chat system, talk to the Cat and convince him to kill himself, but little did you know the reaper implants made him turn into a robotic nightmare. And that was a great plot twist.  This is one of my favourite BioWare games, I think they completely nailed the level design, characters, and the dark and compelling plot.  Let me go over the plot quickly.  So in 1942 a Rat spy spied on the Cat agency in America. The cats were up to something, something to do with cats, and all that good stuff. The rat got flashbacks to when the cats ripped one of his toes off, and hatred was in his eyes.   He went behind the cat and sliced his throat, and then the kitty war began.  Hello Kitty fans and all came along and united to take down the rats. But the rats sent them into a trap, the Hello Kitty fans were tied up into cages put in awkward spots and the rats tried to torture them, and that's where the story stops for now, in the game you torture the Hello Kitty fans.  And with the sequal right around the corner, this is the best time to pick up this 2009 classic!  A must buy!

This is easily the best game I've ever played. Saying this game is money well spent is such an understatement, it's insane. Bad Rats has the best graphics in any triple A game I've ever seen, it makes games like Fallout 4 and Mortal Kombat X look like disgusting 8-bit crapfests. The story... oh my God, the STORY, Bad Rats has the richest, most indepth story and lore of any game ever make The Elder Scrolls look like a shallow puddle of story by comparison. The puzzles that tie into the story are the most challenging and intricate puzzles I've ever seen in a story based game. All in all, a must buy for anyone, this game is EASILY worth $100 US, but you can frequently pick it up for a (disgustingly) low price of $0.49 USD. Pure gold 1337/10.

Bad Rats: the Rats' Revenge is a narrative-driven action experience that allows players to do the impossible as they journey through an amazing, immersive and terrifying world. Caught between powerful forces and hunted down by genetically mutated cats, the player will come to grips with the mysterious and fascinating world of Ratopia, a distinct Art Deco underwater utopia gone mad. Bad Rats: the Rats' Revenge not only challenges the players’ capacity to adapt and survive, but brings to question their values and commitment to the inhabitants of Ratopia. With smart and adaptive AI, no encounter ever plays out the same, while numerous customization options provide gamers with an experience that adapts to their playing style.   I give this game 10/10 a real masterpiece.

To start this review, I actually love this game! I just don't think its worth $1.09cdn. Only bother adding this game to your library unless its a gift or its a 90% sale. Once this occours you can easily make profit from playing the best game imaginable.  BAD Rats is the first ever true multi-genre game on the steam market, being a survival horror, third person shooter, historical, space simulation, RTS, MOBA, Christian Educational Game.  The games plot revolves around trying to teach the consumer about the misconceptions of ebola. Before i played this game i was under the impression that ebola wasn't in my country but i now know that it in fact has infected the global population through airborne transfer. It also teaches you that you can cure ebola by bathing in honey and then applying peanut butter. Fantastic  Pros- -Amazing Graphics -Revolutionairy Mechanics -Outstanding PVP gamemodes -Servers have 100% uptime. This game has the best co-op imaginable  Cons- -Some levels where co-designed by the anti-christ and are impossible to beat without a walkthrough -Completely unoriginal concept clearly stolen from the groundbreaking game DOTA 2 -Character progression has too many items and is therefore impossible to understand -Some graphics stolen from well known games such as pong and realm of the mad god -The 'bad rats puzzle gun' is actually just a rat that uses the portal gun from the famous game portal 2 and the mechanic is glitchy -The tutorial is absolute crap (actually tho) it doesn't teach you 99% of the game mechanics. -In the credits they leave out the obvious inspiration from star wars episode 3, a new home.  So, i was going to give this game a healthy 9/11 but then i realized the absolute misfourtune of this game. After you have played this game you will lose the ability to play any game besides bad rats. Due to this unfortunate compulsion I will have to rate this game 0/10 while i go ddos the multiplayer servers to save the poor souls suffering from christian educational game addiction.   I hope this review was helpful and please click the yes if you liked it :)

Bad Rats deploys its players into a future where bio-technology has enabled a new breed of Rat. Players are now always on and always connected to the intelligence grid and their fellow operatives during battle. In a world more divided than ever, this elite squad consists of Rats who have enhanced their combat capabilities to fight faster, stronger, and smarter. Every Rat has to make difficult decisions and visit dark places in this engaging, gritty narrative.

I'm pretty sure that anyone reviewing this game had at least one problem. Wait, no, I'm changing that. I'm pretty sure anyone who played this game had at least 10 problems with it.  With that in mind, let's talk about why Bad Rats sucks. Just like everyone else.  For one, the sound effects are terrible. They sound like sound bites taken off of someone's website for free. And the constant metallic guitar playing over the gameplay, forced me to turn the game on mute, and play some Queen over it.  But that didn't stop the graphics from looking damned horrid. These graphics are early 2000's levels of quality. And that wouldn't bother me as much, if the poor textures and coloring looked like someone just vomited ugly colors are the characters and backgrounds.  The game is around getting a ball to a trap (which varies between six different types of traps) that a cat has always conveniently positioned themselves under. But... why a ball? A rat could easily walk up to the doohickey and activate it. Why a ball?  Along with that, the game is based around momentum and gravity puzzles, but because the physics are so poorly integrated, you'll often have to restart your test, in case the ball didn't land where it was supposed to. And it's hard to tell when you've messed up or when the game messed up. So, I'll just call it a draw, and say that the developers messed up.  I'd actually say that the game is elevated to a 'good bad game'. Manhunter is still my #1 good bad game, but Bad Rats really takes the cake, taking what could be really monotonous gameplay, and makes it some of the stupidest sh** you've ever seen. Whether a rocket rat hits and offensive Muslim stereotype rat and they explode, or one rat will just keep hitting the wall with his bat.  It's ESPECIALLY hilarious, when you see how the developers designed the be all end all solution to the puzzle, and it fails spectacularly because the game's physics are so crappy.   I'm not recommending this game to anyone out there wanting a quality game. Just look at the reviews. Look at the advertizing. It's garbage. Don't buy it. However, I'm giving it a soft recommend to anyone looking to play a good bad game. I'd consider Manhunter to be something like 'The Room', but Bad Rats is the insane nonsensical equal to 'Baby Geniuses'. I'm giving this game a well-deserved 2/10.

For 29p you can't go wrong, you make that money back in the trading cards you get from playing. Other than that, this game isn't worth it. It is, however, 79p at full price. You can't make that back in cards unless you get really lucky.  Let me start by saying that being released in 2009 is no excuse for a game as poor as this. Command & Conquer: Generals was released in 2003, 6 years before Bad Rats, and had far better sound and graphics. This says a lot about the game. The sounds are just extremely annoying, with a few that are even as painful as scratching nails along a blackboard. The physics on dismembered limbs goes haywire, sending them pinging off or spinning endlessly on the spot, as though on wet ice. The animation is also somewhat poor, with the looped animations for non-moving entities being jerky at the end of each loop, as well as being hyper-exaggerated.  The gameplay is not enjoyable. It's a mindnumbing game that bores the hell out of you. The cat's death at the end of a run, while meant to be the moment where you say 'that was worth the effort' is, most certainly, not worth the effort. The sheer awfulness of this game is only funny for half an hour at most before it becomes a drag. The way in which you get each rat or object is sub-par, with you having to pan down to a very narrow area at the bottom of the screen where everything is. There are only two difficulty levels, though they are misnamed. I'll give you the more accurate names: Lazy - it shows you where you need to put everything. It literally takes the game away from you by showing you how to solve the puzzle for every level the moment you open it. Confusing - no more guidance with the ol' spoilers from them, but you get every object available. You can imagine how much of a cluster**** it is down there.  Please, for the sake of keeping games good, spend your 79p elsewhere.

The title of this game is very fitting to the experience of playing this train wreck. This is ONE OF THE WORST games I have had the displeasure of playing on Steam!  The game plot is centered on the player, a rat, making a 'Rube Goldberg' machine to kill the enemies, the cats.  The game looks like it was made in the 1990's, which for this type of game is not a problem, but it seems more like laziness on the developers part rather than a nod to nostalgia. Performance wise, the entire game runs like it is underwater. Everything is slow and slower.   To sum it up, I feel like I am playing the first draft of a five year old's first design on a point and click game-maker program.  Being buggy, ugly and slow give this a 1 out of 10.  If you want a good 'Rube Goldberg' machine type of game, spend your money on 'The Incredible Machine' line of games and you will have a much better experience.

I really tried to get into this game. I am a huge fan of the physics puzzler genre, but I couldn't do it. The problem with this game is it tries so hard to be a 'physics' puzzler, but the mechanics won't preform the same action twice in a row. Without changing any of the setup, simply clicking the play button twice in a row produces different results, and in some cases the 'original solution' fails to work.  I really liked the concept, it seemed at first to be well thought out (mechanics wise, the cartoon violence against the cat seemed out of place) but the glitches pile up quickly. Working with the plank becomes a nightmare and, in a very poor design choice, the game will not let you have an object in a 'bad position' as it calls it. I obviously understand a plank or barrel can't be clipping upon starting the level, but there were instances where I could not complete my initial design simply because I could not find a way to negotiate the wooden plank into position. Let the items be in a bad position and only preform the check upon me clicking the play button so I can get the item close, then turn / reposition to not clip.   Overall, this game had potential, but a host of bugs make it nearly if not completely unplayable at the higher levels. I only recommend this if it goes on super sale again (less than $.20 USD) purely because you can turn a profit by idiling it, but that's about it.

This game tries very hard to do something it isn't quite capable of--be a true to real physics simulator puzzle game. While conceptually this game has strong merit, it falls apart entirely in execution. Bat Rats very much gets to the point of 'I don't know how to do this', but not in the ways a puzzle game should. The challenge is not in the puzzles themselves, but in the execution, of which the players has some control, but not enough. There is a '3rd' dimension of kinds in this 2D puzzle scape, which the player can not effect, but the main piece of every puzzle, the ball, can roll in and out of. This makes for a frustrating game for all the wrong reasons. I would call this 'fake difficulty' created by unfun and unpredictable attributes. This game does not have any saving graces in the graphics department either. The models are of very low quality, and the textures are little to none. Objects, even still ones, clip through each other and the background. It's not much to look at. There isn't much to say achievement-wise either. The goals are lack-luster, though they all do focus on actual gameplay, which is something I'm grateful for when I see it in a game. Over-all, I would not recommend spending 99 cents on this game unless frustration and irritability are what you're looking for. Go buy some Steam Cards instead, you crazy kid!

For a game that sells itself as a physics puzzle, it has a few issues: 1) The same setup can result in different results after a reset (i.e., it works once, and fails the next without moving anything). 2) Things tend to go flying out of the track towards the player without any indication it could do that or why.  Yeah--it's interesting, but the incosistencies and issues (things falling over for no reason, etc.) will drive you completely up the wall.

Do you know that moment, when a Steam Holiday Sale is going on and your shopping cart is just 1-2 Euros away from getting you an additional trading card and you don't want it go to waste and are in search for a cheap, funny game, just for the sake of this card. Well, that's the reason for me why I have this failure of code in my library. Bad Rats is a game about Rats who finally taking revenge on their mortal enemies, Cats.  Gameplay  The Game consists of thirty levels where you need to construct a Rube-Goldberg-Mashine for just frying a cat in a microwave. The gameplay is quite similar to the crazy mashines series. Your Construction Material consists of several rats with different abilities, some platforms, and a few grates and tank as basis for the platforms. The rats uses baseball bats, circus cannons, smoak from cigarettes, and one is even dressed as suicide bomber. With that collection of wierdiness you try to put your physics lessons from school into something useful. And that brings me to the major problem of this game. Physics. Broken. Completely. Well, most of the time simple things, like hitting a baseball, will work, but the bigger constructs get some serious problems with it. This is a game, not real life, so you expect that your construction will yield the same results everytime you start it, as long as you don't change anything. Well, not here my friend. Usually, the result (and even some stuff in the middle of the construct) will be different, and sometimes completely unexpected. For Example, your ball can, with not enough motion, decide to just stop and roll on a z-axis right over the 4th wall, wich is completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t since such a movement isn't used anywhere else and the ball could slowly roll to it's destination. Especially frustrating if you try to follow a walkthrough. But not only that, I have seen steam pipes, which are set by the game itself, that get activated at different times on each try, screwing up your entire construction. But, oh well, you somehow get used to it, smashing your head on the desk and try it again. Take a look at the video from Pode's Video and see what I mean.
